ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about modern technology like electric cars, water filtration, Kroon Hall, etc.
I learned a vast amount of information regarding electric vehicles, energy, and public policies.
I learned about everyday technologies and their historical development. I also thought it was interesting to see how Yale is taking action to help the environment.

I learned a lot about Yale's campus and what goes on behind the scenes. I felt I was able to develop some critical thinking skills as well within this course. I was pushed to think about causes and effects of things like solar energy, and how to really investigate things below surface level. For example, the use of electric cars is more beneficial depending on the state (and how that state receives its energy).

I learned a relatively superficial amount about a broad range of technologies now. I particularly learned about energy, and its associated issues, as that was an interest of mine. I also learned a lot about the Yale campus. I heard about the technology involved in powering Yale and its buildings and also saw different STEM facilities.
I learned a lot more about how the world around me works. One particular skill that I developed was the ability to present my research in an interesting way to a group of my peers.
How to find credible sources, how to self-study, how to ask questions in anticipation of psets, how to apply knowledge of atomic physics to modern inventions.
I learned about modern technology policies, the science behind them, and the challenges to make them feasible.
I did learn a lot about the technology behind a lot of our current everyday devices.
I gained greater knowledge about science and how its used in modern tech
In this course, we learned a lot about energy and water systems, climate policies, computing, and even a little Yale history.
knowledge on energy policies in the US and quantum physics
I learned a lot about different conversions as well as where technology we have today comes from.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: extremely low workload (just 3 homeworks, a midterm, and a final project), fairly interesting if you like science.  You take several tours in the second half of the semester where you learn about the specific facitilies Yale has, such as the CEID, Kroon Hall, or that one building with a quantum computer in the basement.  Also the professor is very sweet, and sometimes gives out trinkets in class.

Weakness: kind of boring if you don't like science.

I think the course could improve by having more student-to-student discussions rather than the teacher just lecturing for the majority of the time. In this way, it could be more of a seminar. The field trips and guest lectures were a neat touch.

It really enjoyed learning about a lot of different things, but I feel because we covered so much, I wasn't able to grasp anything fully. It also would've been nice to have the guest lectures sprinkled in the course evenly and not just saved for the end because they were pretty fun!

Strengths - visiting and learning about the campus. Had some very interesting speakers. 

Weaknesses - a lot of repetition. Felt like we mentioned governor Newsom's energy policies 3-4 times. More content with less repetition would help.

A strength of this course is the guest lectures. I learned a lot about what people did in their careers and gained insight into the type of research or studies people work on after graduation. I think a weakness of this course could be a less student collaboration than I expected. I don't think I came out of this course with many close friends.

Strengths: interesting incorporation of sustainability, engaging topics.

Weaknesses: not much discussion/participation of students, sometimes too much like a lecture.

Very low workload and overall a good science credit class. Weaknesses: I feel like some concepts were brushed too quickly, and the mid-term was brutal in terms of time (+30 written questions to answer in 1h15, actually less because it took 15 minutes to start the test).
I think that there shouldve been more review for the midterm. I also think a clearer syllabus for the midterm would've been nice.

Strengths: very comprehensive 

Weaknesses: concepts were only explained once, so difficult concepts were very hard to grasp (without the helpful repetition or reexplanation that often accompanies such explanations)
The topics that the course covers are a bit miscellaneous, but I did find everything we covered interesting and topical.
My strengths are topics that involve the environment and my weaknesses are some of the scientists that we were required to memorize.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!  If you want an easy science credit or a low-stress introduction to technology like electric cars, etc.  No, if you are a hardcore science student looking for intellectual challenge or rigorous study.
Yes! I learned a lot while not having too much pressure put on me.

I would. It is a very good introduction to science for non-scientists. If you want a high degree of rigour or know science well, this is not for you. However, as a humanities student, it was worth it.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student who is interested learning about science through a macro perspective rather than learning the nitty gritty details in other science credit courses.
Yes. You learn about interesting inventions on a deep level that you might not otherwise learn about. Its engaging but not too challenging, it wont need to be prioritized before your other classes.
If you are looking for a science credit with a low workload, that's the class! Professor Prober is also a really nice person and very understanding, so I would definitely recommend taking this class.
I think I would. It's an easy science credit and the grading is pretty generous. Just do good on the midterm and stay on top of the hw.
No. I think the class doesnt teach much in the way of useful knowledge, and its very memorization heavy, which makes it a struggle to do the work.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! We learned a lot about some extremely relevant topics such as energy policy and quantum computing.
I would recommend it to another student because it was fairly easy. However, the material is often boring.
